title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" and authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including supportive housing and services promoting health and wellness. Leases can be for a term not exceeding 50 years to third parties. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families. These purposes include health promotion, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support services, transportation, and services supporting these purposes. The lease term should not exceed 10 years. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can lease real property at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus to The Regents of the University of California for up to 10 years. The lease must align with the campus master plan and focus on providing services to veterans. The Regents must agree to offer additional services as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can lease real property at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus to The Regents of the University of California for up to 10 years. The lease must align with the campus master plan and focus on providing services to veterans. The Regents must offer additional services that benefit veterans and their families, including those who are severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless, such as medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling activities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can lease real property at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus to The Regents of the University of California for up to 10 years, with a focus on providing services to veterans. The Regents must offer additional services that benefit veterans and their families, including medical, clinical, therapeutic, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling activities. The Secretary may not carry out any land-sharing agreement at the Campus unless it provides additional health-care resources and benefits veterans and their families. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can lease real property at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus to The Regents of the University of California for up to 10 years, with a focus on providing services to veterans. Any funds received from the lease shall be used for the renovation and maintenance of the Campus. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public transportation purposes. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus to local public transportation authorities and the State of California for public utilities. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public utilities, with improvements subject to specified terms. Easements will be terminated if abandoned, and the property will revert to the United States. The Secretary is prohibited from selling real property or improvements at the Campus to third parties. The Secretary must ensure consistency with the Master Plan. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public utilities, with improvements subject to specified terms. Easements will be terminated if abandoned, and the property will revert to the United States. The Secretary is prohibited from selling real property or improvements to third parties. Each lease must be consistent with the approved master plan. If the Department is found to be non-compliant with Federal laws relating to leases and land use, the Secretary may not enter into any lease or land-sharing agreement. The Secretary is prohibited from entering into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus that is not in compliance with laws until all audit report recommendations are implemented. Leases must comply with chapter 33 of title 41, United States Code. The Secretary must comply with laws and audit report recommendations before entering into any lease at the Campus. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs to improve services for veterans and their families. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs, comprised of members including veterans, family members, advocates, service providers, and stakeholders. The Board will provide opportunities for community collaboration, focus on local issues such as health care, benefits, and memorial services. The Secretary must notify Congress and local representatives 45 days before entering into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus. Additionally, an annual report is required one year after the agreement. The Secretary must notify Congress and local representatives 45 days before entering into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus. An annual report evaluating all leases and agreements must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs, including revenue management and required records. The Inspector General must submit reports on all leases and land management at the Campus to Congress every two and five years after the enactment of the Act. The Inspector General must submit reports on land management at the Campus, including efforts to implement the master plan. The Secretary has the authority to enter into agreements regarding the Campus as long as they are authorized by law and not inconsistent with this section. The term "Principally Benefit Veterans and Their Families" is defined. The term "Principally Benefit Veterans and Their Families" is defined as services provided exclusively to veterans and their families, or designed for their particular needs, excluding services that only generate revenue for them. The text discusses provisions related to services benefiting veterans and their families, excluding those that solely generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Additionally, there are conforming amendments regarding property disposal and enhanced-use leases under the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016. The text discusses provisions related to services benefiting veterans and their families, excluding those that solely generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Additionally, there are conforming amendments regarding property disposal and enhanced-use leases under the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016. The enhanced-use lease under the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016 shall be considered.
